abstract.p: Pearl Duncan letter on her use of DNA to trace her African roots

block.p: Re ''DNA Offers Link to Black History'' (news article, Aug. 28): I am an African-American writer who has found my African ancestors by matching my father's Y-chromosome DNA to that of 30 African families.

Re ''DNA Offers Link to Black History'' (news article, Aug. 28): I am an African-American writer who has found my African ancestors by matching my father's Y-chromosome DNA to that of 30 African families.

I traced nicknames in my family back to the 1650's in Africa and used journals of slave agents and planters to identify them as Akan people of Ghana. I used their land records and certificates of births, baptisms and deaths to follow them into the 1690's in Jamaica. A geneticist compared my father's Y-chromosome DNA with the DNA of 30 African families I had identified. They matched, and I have met the descendants of my ancestors from the Akuapim people, from the villages of Akropong, Aburi, Lateh, Mamfe and Mampong in the hills overlooking the ocean and the capital, Accra.
I am descended from farmers shipped to the coast when they lost civil wars and battles over their farmlands.
